clinical_study.official_title: Bipolar Scissors Versus Classic Method for Circumcision

brief_summary.textblock: comparing the outcomes of using bipolar scissors for male circumcision to the classic scalpel method

detailed_description.textblock: A prospective, randomized study, comparing two different techniques for pediatric male circumcision: the bipolar diathermy scissors technique with that of a classic scalpel technique. Study included male infants from 40 days old up to 18 month old. They were reviewed regarding Operative time, bleeding, complications, postoperative pain and morbidity. Differences in the outcome were compared.

study_design_info.intervention_model_description: Comparing Outcomes of two different surgical techniques between two groups

primary_outcome.description: occurrence of active bleeding after circumcision

secondary_outcome.description: pain after operation as assessed and described by parents (through a questionnaire) by the Neonatal/Infant Pain Scale (NIPS): It is composed of six (6) indicators. facial expression cry breathing patterns arms legs state of arousal Each behavioral indicator is scored with 0 or 1 except "cry", which has three possible descriptors therefore, being scored with a 0, 1 or 2. Infants should be observed for one minute in order to fully assess each indicator. Total pain scores range from 0-7. Pain Level is determined as: 0-2 = mild to no pain. 3-4 = mild to moderate pain >4 = severe pain
occurrence of infection, necrosis or skin loss around wound
Duration of procedure of both techniques
Excessive or insufficient removal of foreskin (presence of redundant skin or compression of penile length)

arm_group.description: Group of male infants undergoing circumcision using bipolar scissors to separate the foreskin
Group of male infants undergoing circumcision using classic scalpel to separate the foreskin, and sutures to control bleeding

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Male infant between 40 days and 18 month old
- parents' request and approval of circumcision
Exclusion Criteria:
- previous attempts of circumcision or revision cases
- bleeding tendency
- congenital anomalies involving genitalia
- age below 40 days (expected Vit. K deficiency) or above 18 month old.
